To the Sea, to the Sea! The white gulls are crying

wikitext.*:
[[File:Eric Faure-Brac - Tuor.jpg|thumb|250px|''Tuor'' by [[:Category:Images by Eric Faure-Brac|Eric Faure-Brac]]]]
{{quote|To the Sea, to the Sea! The white gulls are crying,
The wind is blowing, and the white foam is flying.|From [[To the Sea, to the Sea! The white gulls are crying|the poem]] sung by [[Legolas]] in ''[[The Return of the King]]'', "[[The Field of Cormallen]]"}}
'''Gulls''' or '''mews''' were birds found on all shores in [[Arda]]. ==History== Gulls were common in all sea-bordering lands (perhaps especially abundant on the cape of [[Ras Mewrim|Bar-in-Mŷl]], the "Home of the Gulls", in the land of the [[Falas]]), and for that, they were often attributed to [[Ossë]].{{LT2|III}} The [[Teleri]] that dwelt in the [[Havens]] were very fond of them, and their mewing welcomed [[Tuor]] to their land.{{UT|1}} They were also known in [[Númenor]]{{UT|4}} and [[Gondor]].{{RK|V9}} Their association with the sea caused a great sense of longing for the journey to [[Valinor]] among [[Elves]] that were not familiar with their sound. One of those was [[Legolas]]. ==Etymology== In the ''[[The Etymologies|Etymologies]]'', one [[Noldorin]] and one [[Quenya]] word for "gull" appear, both from the same root: ''[[maew]]'' and ''[[maiwë]]''.{{LR|Etymologies}} ([[Sundocarme|Root]] [[MIW]]) A later recorded [[Sindarin]] word is ''[[mŷl]]'',{{WJ|Quendi}}, pp. 379, 418 (note 8) which replaced ''gwael''. In manuscripts related to the ''Etymologies'' Tolkien also experimented with the Noldorin form ''cuen'', glossed as "small gull, petrel".{{VT|45a}}, p. 24 ==Other versions of the legendarium== In the earliest version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]'', the [[house of the Wing]] wore [[swans|swan]] or gull-like feathers on their helmets. In the [[1937]] ''[[Quenta Silmarillion (Lost Road)|Quenta Silmarillion]]'', the [[Lindar]] were at one point considered the "Lords of the Gulls" among many other names.{{LR|Quenta}}, p. 215 ==Other fiction== In the story ''[[Roverandom]]'', a seagull named Mew brings the dog Rover to the moon. On their way, Mew stops to visit other sea-birds, among them the "''oldest and most important of all the Blackbacked Gulls''".{{HM|R}}, "[Chapter] 2" {{references}} [[Category:Birds]]
